newsitem.title: UK: GDR REPORT - Indian GDRs slip with Bombay.
newsitem.headline: GDR REPORT - Indian GDRs slip with Bombay.

text.p: Indian global depositary receipts finished easier in continued quiet trade on Tuesday, following a dip in local stocks earlier, traders said.

They said the market was struggling for clear direction, but could pick up on Wednesday if news that the regional Tamil Maanila Congress party had decided to rejoin the government supported stocks in India.
But high GDR premiums to local stocks precluded an independent rise in GDR prices.
Kerb trade in India following the official market close indicated that the benchmark Bombay 30-share index could rise some 40 to 50 points, traders in India said.
Traders said the market would also focus on the 1997/8 budget which is due to go to parliament this week.
Tata shed 41 cents to $11.75/12.75 and Reliance picked up 35 cents to $19.50/$20.00. SBI slipped seven cents to $23.75/$24.75.
The HSBC James Capel Indian GDR index JCEAI closed 0.71 points down at 80.19, with the premium over the local market at 20.69 percent from 21.05 percent.
The Bombay Stock Exchange 30 share index slipped 16.86 to 3,808.65.
Lebanese GDR Solidere picked up a strong $2.20 to $17.25/$17.75 amid investor interest in the issue, which debuted in November at $11.50.
A drop in Taipei stocks sparked declines in the Capel Taiwan GDR Index, which shed 2.73 points to 128.38, representing a discount to the local market of 2.38 percent.
The Capel Korea GDR Index dipped 0.71 points to 63.96 points, a premium of 30.45 percent over the local market.
